A group $G$ is *virtually abelian* (or *abelian-by-finite*) if it has an

More generally, let $\chi$ be a property of groups. A group $G$ is
*virtually $\chi$* if it has a subgroup of finite index with the
property $\chi$. A group $G$ is *$\chi$-by-finite* if it has a normal
subgroup of finite index with the property $\chi$. Note that every
$\chi$-by-finite group is virtually $\chi$, and the converse also holds
if the property $\chi$ is inherited by subgroups.

These notions are obviously only of relevance to infinite groups, as all
finite groups are virtually trivial (and trivial-by-finite).
